phases.name: Fundamentum
phases.subtitle: Foundation
phases.description: Building the relationship foundation through child-directed interaction

lessons.title: Introduction to PRIDE
lessons.subtitle: The foundation of positive interaction
lessons.description: Learn the PRIDE skills that form the foundation of positive parent-child interaction: Praise, Reflect, Imitate, Describe, and Enjoy.
objectives: Understand the purpose of child-directed interaction
Practice identifying PRIDE skills in examples

custosContent.briefing: PRIDE skills come from Parent-Child Interaction Therapy (PCIT), one of the most evidence-based approaches to improving parent-child relationships. These skills help build warmth, reduce conflict, and increase cooperation.
keyPoints: Praise: Specific, labeled praise is more effective than general praise
Reflect: Mirroring your child's words shows you're listening
Imitate: Copying their actions shows interest and builds connection
Describe: Narrating play teaches vocabulary and shows attention
Enjoy: Genuine enthusiasm makes interactions rewarding

assignment.description: Practice one 15-minute PRIDE session with your child

lessons.title: Labeled Praise
lessons.subtitle: Specific recognition of positive behavior
lessons.description: Master the art of labeled praise—specific, descriptive praise that tells your child exactly what they did well.
objectives: Distinguish between labeled and unlabeled praise
Use labeled praise during play sessions

custosContent.briefing: Research shows that labeled praise is significantly more effective than general praise like 'Good job!' Children learn faster and feel more confident when they know specifically what they did right.
keyPoints: Include the specific behavior: 'I love how you shared the crayons!'
Use enthusiasm in your voice
Praise effort and process, not just outcomes
Aim for at least 10 labeled praises per session

assignment.description: Complete 3 PRIDE sessions focusing on labeled praise

lessons.title: Reflection Skills
lessons.subtitle: Active listening through mirroring
lessons.description: Learn to reflect your child's words back to them, showing you're truly listening and building their language skills.
objectives: Combine reflections with other PRIDE skills

custosContent.briefing: Reflections are a powerful form of active listening. When you repeat or paraphrase what your child says, they feel heard and validated. This builds trust and encourages more communication.
keyPoints: Reflect the content: Child says 'Look at my tower!' → 'You built a tall tower!'
Reflect emotions: 'You seem really proud of that!'
Avoid questions during reflection—statements are more effective
Simple reflections can be brief but should match their enthusiasm

assignment.description: Complete 3 sessions with focus on reflections

lessons.title: Behavioral Description
lessons.subtitle: Narrating positive actions
lessons.description: Practice describing your child's actions like a sports commentator, keeping attention positive and teaching vocabulary.
objectives: Learn to narrate play without judging
Practice describing actions, not asking questions

custosContent.briefing: Behavioral descriptions are like being a friendly sportscaster of your child's play. You narrate what they're doing without judging or directing. This shows them you're paying attention and teaches new words.
keyPoints: Describe what you see: 'You're stacking the blocks'
Keep it neutral or positive—avoid criticism
Replace questions with descriptions
Match their pace—don't overwhelm with constant commentary

lessons.title: Integration Practice
lessons.subtitle: Combining all PRIDE skills
lessons.description: Put all the PRIDE skills together in fluid, natural practice sessions.
objectives: Combine all five PRIDE skills naturally
Develop a rhythm for shifting between skills

custosContent.briefing: Now that you've practiced each skill individually, it's time to combine them. Don't worry about using them perfectly—focus on staying positive and following your child's lead.
keyPoints: Let your child lead the play—don't direct or suggest
Rotate naturally between skills based on opportunities
Focus on connection, not perfection
Enjoy the time together!

phases.name: Praxis
phases.subtitle: Practice
phases.description: Developing consistency and building habit through regular practice

lessons.title: Building the Habit
lessons.subtitle: Creating consistent practice routines
lessons.description: Establish a sustainable routine for daily PRIDE practice that fits your family's schedule.
objectives: Identify the best time for daily practice

custosContent.briefing: Research shows that 15 minutes of daily PRIDE practice produces significant improvements in just 6-8 weeks. The key is consistency—same time, same place, same routine.
keyPoints: Pick a time when both you and your child have energy
Remove distractions (phones, screens, other activities)
Set a visible timer so both of you know the commitment
Celebrate your streak to build motivation

assignment.description: Complete 7 consecutive days of PRIDE practice

lessons.title: Avoiding Common Pitfalls
lessons.subtitle: What to do (and not do) during special time
lessons.description: Learn to identify and avoid behaviors that undermine connection during child-directed play.
objectives: Practice redirecting yourself when you slip
Understand why questions and commands reduce connection

custosContent.briefing: During PRIDE time, we avoid Commands, Questions, and Criticism (the 'Don't Skills'). These behaviors shift control away from the child and can reduce the positive effects of the interaction.
keyPoints: Avoid commands: Instead of 'Put that there,' describe what they're doing
Reduce questions: Questions demand answers and take the lead
Eliminate criticism: Even gentle corrections undermine the positive focus
If you slip, just return to PRIDE skills—no need to apologize

assignment.description: Track and reduce 'Don't Skills' over 5 sessions

lessons.title: Emotion Coaching Basics
lessons.subtitle: Helping children understand feelings
lessons.description: Begin incorporating emotion coaching into your interactions to help your child develop emotional intelligence.
objectives: Help children connect feelings to experiences

custosContent.briefing: Emotion coaching helps children recognize, understand, and manage their emotions. When we name feelings ('You look frustrated'), we help children develop emotional vocabulary and self-awareness.
keyPoints: Label emotions you observe: 'You seem excited about that!'
Validate all feelings: 'It's okay to feel frustrated'
Avoid dismissing: Never say 'Don't cry' or 'You're fine'
Help connect feelings to causes: 'Are you sad because the tower fell?'

lessons.title: Extending to Daily Life
lessons.subtitle: PRIDE skills beyond special time
lessons.description: Learn to apply PRIDE skills throughout the day, not just during designated practice time.
objectives: Identify opportunities for PRIDE skills in daily routines
Build a more positive overall communication pattern

custosContent.briefing: While dedicated special time is important, the real power of PRIDE comes from using these skills throughout the day. Brief moments of connection add up to transformed relationships.
keyPoints: Look for natural play moments during the day
Use labeled praise during daily routines
Reflect and describe during car rides, meals, etc.
Even 2-3 minute interactions matter

assignment.description: Log 10 brief PRIDE interactions outside special time

phases.name: Imperium
phases.subtitle: Mastery
phases.description: Advanced techniques for challenging situations and emotional regulation

lessons.title: The Respiro Protocol
lessons.subtitle: In-the-moment de-escalation
lessons.description: Master the Respiro protocol for staying calm and helping your child regulate during difficult moments.
objectives: Practice each step in low-stress moments

custosContent.briefing: Respiro (Halt, Retreat, Breathe, Reflect, Resolve) is a systematic approach to de-escalation. Your calm nervous system can help regulate your child's—this is called co-regulation.
keyPoints: Halt: Stop. Don't react in the heat of the moment
Retreat: Create physical and emotional space
Breathe: Use slow breathing to calm your own system
Reflect: Identify feelings (yours and theirs)
Resolve: Choose a thoughtful response

assignment.description: Practice Respiro 5 times (even in non-crisis moments)

lessons.title: Co-Regulation Strategies
lessons.subtitle: Being the calm in their storm
lessons.description: Develop advanced skills for helping your child regulate their emotions through your own calm presence.
objectives: Understand how your state affects your child

custosContent.briefing: Children's nervous systems are still developing. They literally cannot regulate themselves the way adults can. Your calm presence provides the external regulation they need to learn internal regulation.
keyPoints: Your heart rate affects theirs—slow yourself down first
Use a calm, low voice (not a whisper, which can seem threatening)
Get on their physical level
Offer physical comfort if they accept it

assignment.description: Practice co-regulation techniques in 3 challenging moments

lessons.title: Effective Commands
lessons.subtitle: When direction is necessary
lessons.description: Learn to give effective commands when needed, maximizing compliance while maintaining connection.
objectives: Distinguish between necessary and unnecessary commands
Learn the structure of effective commands
Practice giving commands that children can follow

custosContent.briefing: While PRIDE time avoids commands, real life requires them. Effective commands are specific, simple, stated as a statement (not a question), and given one at a time.
keyPoints: Be specific: 'Put your shoes in the closet' not 'Clean up'
Use statements, not questions: 'Time to wash hands' not 'Can you wash your hands?'
One command at a time
Wait 5 seconds for compliance before repeating

assignment.description: Practice effective commands and track compliance

lessons.title: Selective Attention
lessons.subtitle: The power of ignoring
lessons.description: Master the strategic use of attention to shape behavior—ignoring minor misbehavior while praising the opposite.
objectives: Understand attention as a powerful reinforcer
Learn what behaviors to ignore vs. address

custosContent.briefing: Attention is like sunlight for behavior—whatever you shine it on will grow. Strategic ignoring of minor misbehavior combined with heavy praise for good behavior is highly effective.
keyPoints: Ignore: Whining, mild tantrums, attention-seeking
Don't ignore: Dangerous, destructive, or aggressive behavior
When you ignore, truly ignore—no eye contact, no sighing
Immediately praise when the unwanted behavior stops

assignment.description: Practice selective attention for 5 days, logging results

phases.name: Autonomia
phases.subtitle: Independence
phases.description: Teaching self-regulation and transitioning to independence

lessons.title: Teaching Self-Regulation
lessons.subtitle: Helping children manage themselves
lessons.description: Learn to scaffold your child's developing self-regulation skills, gradually reducing support as they grow.

custosContent.briefing: Self-regulation is learned gradually. Children move from needing full external regulation to self-regulation through a process of supported practice. Your role is to scaffold this development.
keyPoints: Start with full support during high emotions
Gradually reduce support as skills develop
Teach coping strategies when calm, not during crises
Celebrate growing independence

lessons.title: Problem Solving Together
lessons.subtitle: Collaborative approaches to challenges
lessons.description: Use collaborative problem solving to address recurring challenges while building your child's thinking skills.

custosContent.briefing: Collaborative Problem Solving treats children as partners in addressing challenges. Instead of imposing solutions, we work together to find approaches that address both your concerns and theirs.
keyPoints: Empathize first: Understand their perspective
Define the problem: Share your concern without blame
Brainstorm together: All ideas are valid initially
Choose together: Find solutions that work for both

assignment.description: Use collaborative problem solving for one recurring issue

lessons.title: Maintaining Gains
lessons.subtitle: Preventing regression
lessons.description: Learn strategies for maintaining your progress and preventing regression during stressful times.

custosContent.briefing: Progress isn't always linear. Stress, transitions, and developmental changes can cause temporary regression. Having a plan helps you maintain gains through challenging periods.
keyPoints: Continue daily special time even when things are good
Watch for early warning signs (increased conflict, reduced connection)
During stress, increase PRIDE time temporarily
Review your skills periodically

assignment.description: Create and document your maintenance plan

lessons.title: Graduation and Next Steps
lessons.subtitle: Celebrating growth and planning ahead
lessons.description: Review your progress, celebrate your growth, and plan for continued development.
objectives: Review skills learned throughout the program

custosContent.briefing: You've completed 12 weeks of intensive practice and learning. Take time to acknowledge how far you've come and plan for continued growth.
keyPoints: Review your session logs—notice the progress
Identify your strongest skills
Note areas for continued focus
Set goals for the next 3 months

assignment.description: Complete the graduation reflection and set future goals
